descriptions:

Title: Economic Fluctuations, Productivity Growth, and Stabilization Policies: A Keynesian Growth Perspective

This project aims to develop a unified framework that integrates Keynesian business cycle theory with endogenous growth theory to better understand the interactions between economic fluctuations, productivity growth, and stabilization policies. The proposed research combines Keynesian aggregate demand fluctuations with endogenous growth theory on productivity, creating a novel Keynesian growth model with heterogeneous firms. The project consists of three parts: Part I focuses on developing a state-of-the-art quantitative endogenous growth model, Part II expands the model to an open economy setting to examine monetary policy, capital flows, and productivity growth interactions, and Part III empirically tests the productivity growth response to business cycle fluctuations and policy interventions.

The project will investigate the behavior of productivity during large recessions, such as the Great Recession, and explore the role of pessimistic expectations in stagnation. Two case studies will be conducted: one examining the effects of Euro inception on capital flows and stagnant productivity growth in recipient countries, and another estimating the empirical response of productivity growth to business cycle fluctuations and policy interventions in the United States and a panel of advanced economies. This research will provide valuable insights into the design of effective stabilization policies that promote productivity growth and mitigate the negative impacts of economic fluctuations. The outcomes of this project will inform policy debates and contribute to a deeper understanding of the complex relationships between economic growth, productivity, and policy interventions.
